intro: Loranthus dependens, commonly known as the mistletoe vine, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches itself to host trees, primarily in the genus Eucalyptus. It lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while producing its own carbohydrates through photosynthesis using light reflected from the host. The plant has a distinctive appearance with small, oval leaves and small, white or yellowish flowers that bloom in summer. Its berries are typically red or yellow and contain sticky seeds that adhere to birds, aiding in seed dispersal. Due to its parasitic nature, it can weaken its host tree if left unchecked.
